greeting.subtitle: I'd like to say something...
greeting.profile:
Hi! I am MMeowhite, a third-year Master's student in State Key Laboratory of Biotherapy at Sichuan University. My major is all of things in the world.

My goal is to push the boundaries of human knowledge and capabilities in Medicine, Computer Science, Mathematics, and Physics. I aspire to develop innovative and intelligent solutions that integrate principles from these fields to tackle complex real-world challenges. Specifically, I am interested in exploring methods that effectively and efficiently leverage multimodal data, advanced computational models, and mathematical frameworks to enhance understanding, decision-making, and problem-solving in science and healthcare. I am also passionate about discovering new interdisciplinary approaches that drive meaningful advancements.

News: I am currently researching on cancer neuroscience. Actively looking for communication and collaboration!

timeline.content: During my undergraduate research at the Institute of Life Sciences, Chongqing Medical University (Sep 2020 – Jun 2023), under the supervision of Assoc. Prof. Yun Xiu, I investigated the role of the NMDA receptor subunit NR3A in the molecular mechanisms of depression. My work involved performing qPCR, Western blotting, and selected behavioral assays on mouse models to explore gene expression and protein regulation related to depressive phenotypes. This research contributed to publications in the Journal of Affective Disorders.

Since June 2023, as a graduate researcher under the supervision of Prof. Canhua Huang at the School of Basic Medicine & Forensic Medicine, Sichuan University, and the State Key Laboratory of Biotherapy, I have been conducting independent research on colorectal cancer stem cells and the mechanisms underlying liver metastasis. My work focuses on engineering exosomes that integrate redox disruption and RNA interference strategies to selectively target cancer stem cells for immunotherapy. In parallel, I analyze single-cell sequencing data to explore how colorectal cancer–derived exosomes influence hepatic lipid accumulation and modulate Kupffer cell signaling pathways. This research has led to a first-author manuscript submitted to the Journal of Nanobiotechnology and co-authored publications in Gut and Biomaterials.

Since June 2024, as a graduate researcher at the School of Basic Medicine & Forensic Medicine, Sichuan University, and the State Key Laboratory of Biotherapy, I have been focusing on integrating multi-omics data through artificial intelligence approaches. My research involves combining single-cell, spatial transcriptomics, metabolomics, and microbiome datasets to develop deep learning predictive models using architectures such as Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) and Transformers. In parallel, I am working on predicting post-translational modifications from protein sequences by leveraging pre-trained protein language models (e.g., ESM, ProtBert) alongside CNN, LSTM, and Transformer frameworks. I have completed comprehensive data preprocessing and established the preliminary model framework, with ongoing efforts in model training and optimization.

featuredPublications.title: Extracellular vesicle-induced lipid dysregulation drives liver premetastatic niche formation in colorectal cancer
featuredPublications.abstract: Liver metastasis is a leading cause of death in colorectal cancer (CRC). This study reveals that extracellular vesicles (EVs) from highly metastatic CRC cells promote hepatic premetastatic niche (PMN) formation by inducing lipid accumulation in the liver. Lipidomic and single-cell analyses showed that enhanced fatty acid (FA) synthesis in CRC cells increases prosteatogenic lipids in EVs, which are mainly taken up by Kupffer cells, triggering TNF-α secretion and further lipid accumulation. Inhibition of FA synthesis or hepatic lipid accumulation significantly reduced EV-induced metastasis. Patient-derived organoid experiments confirmed that blocking FA synthesis mitigates hepatic lipid deposition and liver metastasis. These findings identify FA synthesis inhibition as a promising strategy to prevent CRC liver metastasis.

featuredPublications.authors: Mengmeng Zhang, Xiangru Kong, Jing Chen, Wenqin Liu, Can Liu, Xiaoyun Dou, Lin Jiang, Yanmin Luo, Mingrui Song, Peng Miao, Yong Tang, Yun Xiu
featuredPublications.title: Dysfunction of GluN3A subunit is involved in depression-like behaviors through synaptic deficits
featuredPublications.abstract: GluN3A, an inhibitory subunit of N-methyl-d-aspartate receptors (NMDARs), plays an unclear role in depression. In this study, we examined GluN3A expression in a chronic restraint stress (CRS) mouse model of depression and explored its molecular mechanisms. We found that GluN3A expression was significantly reduced in the hippocampus of CRS mice, and restoring GluN3A expression alleviated depression-like behaviors. Furthermore, GluN3A knockout (KO) mice exhibited symptoms of anhedonia and despair, alongside downregulation of genes involved in synapse and axon development. Reduced PSD95 levels in GluN3A KO mice were rescued by viral re-expression of GluN3A, highlighting its crucial role in regulating synaptic function and depression-related behaviors. Despite these findings, the full mechanism by which GluN3A contributes to depression remains unclear.

research.work: Under the supervision of Assoc. Prof. Xiu Yun, I studied the role of the inhibitory subunit of NMDA receptors, GluN3A, in the pathophysiology of depression. My responsibilities included performing animal behavioral experiments (such as sucrose preference test, forced swim test, and open field test) and recording data, conducting molecular biology assays (protein and RNA extraction, Western Blot, qPCR) to assess synaptic protein levels (e.g., PSD95) and gene expression changes, and participating in project discussions. This work resulted in a publication in the Journal of Affective Disorders. Through this project, I gained systematic experience in linking behavioral and molecular studies, and strengthened my skills in experimental design, data analysis, and scientific writing.

location.name: West China school of Basic Medical Sciences & Forensic Medicine of Sichuan University

research.work: Supervised by Prof. Canhua Huang, my research focuses on colorectal cancer stem cells and liver metastasis, aiming to develop immunotherapeutic strategies targeting cancer stem cells. My work involves constructing engineered exosome delivery systems and combining redox disruption with RNA interference to enhance immunotherapy efficacy. Additionally, I investigate the tumor microenvironment in colorectal cancer liver metastasis, analyzing how CRC-derived exosomes influence hepatic lipid accumulation and Kupffer cell-mediated signaling using single-cell sequencing data. I am independently responsible for experimental design and execution, including exosome modification, RNA interference system construction, validation in cell and animal models, molecular assays (Western Blot, qPCR, ELISA), and phenotypic analyses (DNA damage, ROS detection, flow cytometry), as well as leading manuscript preparation and figure production. Research outcomes include a first-author manuscript submitted to Journal of Nanobiotechnology, and co-authorship on publications in Gut and Biomaterials.

Since July 2024, I have been independently exploring multi-omics data integration using machine learning and deep learning for disease prediction and mechanistic studies. I integrate single-cell RNA-seq, spatial transcriptomics, metabolomics, and host-microbiome data, constructing deep learning predictive models such as graph neural networks (GNNs) and Transformers. For protein sequence analysis, I leverage pre-trained protein language models (ESM, ProtBert) to extract sequence features and apply CNNs, LSTMs, and Transformers for post-translational modification site prediction. The project has completed multi-omics data preprocessing and initial model framework construction, with the next steps involving model fine-tuning and training.
